witness.bibl: "Live with me and be my love", in Roxburghe Ballads, 1603
Poems of Sir Walter Raleigh, ed. Sir Egerton Brydges, 1813

div.head: THE PASSIONATE SHEPHERD TO HIS LOVE
div.l:
Come
live with mee If thou wilt live , and be my love,
And Then we will all the pleasures every pleasure prove,

That Vallies, groves, hills and fieldes hilles and vallies, dales and fields valleis, groves, the hills and filds hills and valleis, groves and filds vallyes groves and woodds or feildes vallies, Groves, or hils, or fields hill or dales woodds or fieldes grove or valley, hill or field ,

Woods, or steepie mountaine yeeldes And all the craggy mountaines yeeld Woods, or steepy Mountaines yeelds Woods and steepest mountaynes yeelds Woods or craggi mountaines yieldes And craggie rockes or mountaines yieldes Or woods and steepie mountains yeelds Rivers or steepy mountaines yieldes Or wood and steepy mountain yield .

And There Where Then
wee will will we
sit sett
upon the on rising Rocks,
Seeing the Sheepheards feede theyr our flocks,
By shallow Rivers, to by whose falls,
Melodious byrds sing sings Madrigalls.

And There Where Pleas'd
I will will I wee will
make lye on
thee
beds a bedd of Roses,

And With Drest with And then And make And twine
a thousand thowsande other
fragrant flagrant
posies poesies poses ,
A cap of flowers, and a rural kirtle,
Imbroydred all with leaves of Mirtle.
A gowne made jaunty gown of the finest wooll,
Which from our pretty the little Lambes we pull,
Fayre lined slippers Slippers lin'd choicely And shoes lin'd choicely for the cold:
With buckles of the purest gold.
A belt of straw, and Ivie buds,
With Corall Amber clasps and Amber studs,
And if If these pleasures may thee things thy mind may delights thy mind may move,
Come Then To live with mee, and be my love.
The Sheepheards Swaines shall daunce and sing,
For thy delight each May-morning.
If these delights thy minde may move;
Then live with mee, and be my love.
